tit.e: Jiju-ｄen Hall (a building in Imperial Palace)
tit.cmt: 用語共有データベースに基づき、書き直し

sen.j: 仁寿殿（じじゅうでん・じんじゅでん）とは、平安京の内裏における殿舎のひとつ。
sen.e: Jiju-den (or Jinju-den) Hall was a building in Imperial Place in the Heian-kyo capital.
Jijuden Hall (or Jinjuden Hall) was one of the halls of the dairi (Imperial Palace) in the city of Heian-kyo.
Jijuden Hall (or Jinjuden Hall) was one of the halls of the dairi (Imperial Palace) in the city of Heian-kyo.

sen.j: 内裏のほぼ中央にあり、紫宸殿の北、承香殿の南、清涼殿の東に位置する。
sen.e: Being almost at the center of Imperial Palace, this hall was located in the north of Shishin-den Hall (hall for state ceremonies), in the south of Shokyo-den Hall and in the east of Seiryo-den Hall (literally, a limpid cool hall).
Situated almost at the center of the Imperial Palace, this hall was located north of the Shishinden Hall (Throne Hall), south of the Shokyoden Hall and east of the Seiryoden Hall.
sen.cmt: ・「Being」→「Situated」・「the」を４つ補足・「in the」を３つ削除・「Shishin-den Hall (hall for state ceremonies)」→「Shishinden (Throne Hall)」・「Shokyo-den」→「Shokyoden」・「Seiryo-den」→「Seiryoden」・「(literally, a limpid cool hall)」を削除
sen.e: Situated almost at the center of the Imperial Palace, this hall was located north of the Shishinden Hall (Throne Hall), south of the Shokyoden Hall and east of the Seiryoden Hall.

sen.j: 平安時代初期に、天皇の日常生活の居所として使用された。
sen.e: In the early Heian period, this building was used as the ordinary living quarter of Emperor.
In the early Heian period, this building was used as the everyday living quarters of emperor.

sen.j: そのため仁寿殿にも天皇が毎朝、伊勢神宮などを遙拝する石灰の壇（いしばいのだん）があった。
sen.e: Therefore, an Ishibai-no-dan platform was also placed in Jiju-den Hall for Emperor to say a prayer every morning in the direction of Ise-jingu and other shrines.
It is for this reason that Jijuden Hall also had an ishibai-no-dan (lime altar) at which the emperor would pray in the direction of Ise-jingu and other shrines each morning.

sen.j: 天皇の住まいが清涼殿へ移ってからは、相撲節会、内宴、元服の儀式など各種行事を行う場所になった。
sen.e: After Emperor's residence was moved to Sheiryo-den Hall, this hall was used for various events, including Sumai no sechie (the Imperial ceremony of Sumo wrestling), naien (private dinners) and ceremonies of attaining manhood.

After the emperor's residence was moved to Seiryoden Hall, Jijuden Hall was used for various events including Sumai no Sechie (the Imperial ceremony of Sumo wrestling), naien (private dinners) and genpuku (male coming-of-age ceremonies).
